casebody.data:
In the Matter of Burton B. Roberts, as District Attorney of Bronx County, Appellant, v. County Court of Wyoming County et al., Respondents. Argued April 29, 1974; decided June 5, 1974. *247Mario Merola, District Attorney (Dwight D. Darcy of counsel), for appellant.

I. The action of the Wyoming County Court sought to be enjoined was nonfinal and therefore nonappealable. (People v. Hudson, 19 N Y 2d 137; Matter of Proskin v. County Ct. of Albany County, 30 N Y 2d 15; People ex rel. Duryee v. Duryee, 188 N. Y. 440; People ex rel. Tatra v. McNeill, 19 A D 2d 845; People ex rel. Farnum v. Superintendent of Matteawan State Hosp., 18 A D 2d 1104; People ex rel. Bernoff v. Jackson, 269 App. Div. 580; Matter of Lee v. County Ct. of Erie County, 27 N Y 2d 432; Matter of Hogan v. Court of Gen. Sessions, 296 N. Y. 1.) II. The petition seeking article 78 relief was timely filed. (Matter of Myricks v. Kennedy, 6 Misc 2d 854; Matter of Central School Dist. No. 2 v. New York State Teachers’ Retirement System, 27 A D 2d 265, 23 N Y 2d 213.) III. The Wyoming County Court lacked jurisdiction to entertain relator Pugach’s *248writ of habeas corpus and exceeded its authority in ordering a hearing to take place in Bronx County. (People ex rel. Keitt v. McMann, 18 N Y 2d 257; People v. Warren, 34 A D 2d 1020; Matter of Hogan v. Culkin, 18 N Y 2d 330; People ex rel. Cunningham v. McNeill, 306 N. Y. 645; People ex rel. Sedlak v. Foster, 299 N. Y. 291; Matter of Morhous v. Supreme Ct. of State of N. Y., 293 N. Y. 131; People ex rel. Jarrels v. Mancusi, 35 A D 2d 685; People ex rel. Negron v. Herold, 34 A D 2d 1047; People ex rel. Thompson v. Mancusi, 33 A D 2d 643; People ex rel. Anderson v. Warden, N. Y. City Correctional Inst. for Men, 68 Misc 2d 463.)

Hayden H. Dadd for Wyoming County Court, respondent.

I. The appeal is moot. II. The first sentence of. CPLR 7011 specifically provides for an appeal. III. The court’s solution of applying the statute on ad hoc basis avoids both extremes and is eminently fair and practical.

Richard T. Farrell for Burton N. Pugach, respondent.

Since the determination of the habeas corpus proceeding was final, appellant’s sole relief from that judgment was through appeal. (People ex rel. Prosser v. Martin, 306 N. Y. 710.)

Per Curiam.

Judgment, denominated an order, in an article 78 proceeding in the nature of prohibition affirmed, without costs, on the limited ground that it was improvident to entertain the proceeding to prohibit the exercise of jurisdiction by the habeas corpus court. The habeas corpus court had jurisdiction to entertain the writ (CPLR 7004) and power to order a hearing to be held by the sentencing court (see, e.g., People ex rel. Prosser v. Martin, 306 N. Y. 710, 711-712). Hence, prohibition, which might be available to restrain a court from proceeding without jurisdiction or in excess of its powers, does not lie (see Matter of Proskin v. County Ct. of Albany County, 30 N Y 2d 15, 18; Matter of Lee v. County Ct. of Erie County, 27 N Y 2d 432, 436-437; Matter of Hogan v. Culkin, 18 N Y 2d 330, 336; cf. Matter of Marx v. Holloran, 236 App. Div. 680). Moreover, it would appear to be unseemly to invoke a summary proceeding to restrain proceedings under the constitutional writ (N. Y. Const., art. I, § 4). The evident unseemliness is further aggravated by the availability of an appeal, under *249CPLR 7011, from a judgment of habeas corpus (see Matter of Lee v. County Ct., supra, p. 437). Nor was the judgment any less final, for purposes of appeal, because it, in effect, directed a further hearing in the criminal action by the sentencing court (cf. People ex rel. Prosser v. Martin, supra). Prohibition does not ordinarily lie if there be an adequate remedy by way of appeal (Matter of Lee v. County Ct., supra).

In light of this disposition, the court does not consider the several grounds adopted by the Appellate Division in its opinion dismissing the petition. It is noted, also, that the controversy has been mooted: the Supreme Court in Bronx County conducted the postconviction hearing directed by the habeas corpus court, and found that the prisoner, Pugach, had been competent to stand trial in 1962.

Chief Judge Breitel and Judges Jasen, Jones, Wachtler, Rabin and Stevens concur in Per Curiam opinion; Judge Gabbielli taking no part.

Judgment affirmed, without costs.
